title: login: Shiny Login Module
text: login_server() function handles server side functionality must added Shiny server function. following examples provides basic functionality using SQLite database basic SMTP email server. APP_ID must unique identifier Shiny module. possible one login module per Shiny application. example, using one important use ID server UI components. login_server() returns shiny::reactiveValues() object two elements can use: logged_in TRUE user logged FALSE otherwise username contains username logged . db_conn parameter can take database connection DBI R package. emailer parameter function three parameters: to_email, subject, message. emayili_emailer helper function wraps emayili R package sending emails SMTP. source code function included serve template wrapping methods sending email. additional_fields character vector defining data collected users create account. data used login package stored users table (defined users_table parameter). values used input labels names column names. cookie_username specifies name cookie saved users enter username password subsequent visits. Set NULL disable cookies. Users can still opt cookies checking “Remember ” check box login UI. salt parameter defines extra layer encryption storing passwords database. minimum, passwords hashed using MD5 algorithm. details provided .
code: APP_ID <- 'my_login_app' # It is recommended that this is defined in global.R library(login) USER <- login::login_server(     id = APP_ID,     db_conn = RSQLite::dbConnect(RSQLite::SQLite(), 'users.sqlite'),     emailer = emayili_emailer(         email_host = email_host,         email_port = email_port,         email_username = email_username,         email_password = email_password,         from_email = reset_password_from_email     ),     additional_fields = c('first_name' = 'First Name',                           'last_name' = 'Last Name'),     cookie_name = 'loginusername',     salt = APP_ID ) emayili_emailer <- function(         email_host = NULL,         email_port = NULL,         email_username = NULL,         email_password = NULL,         from_email = NULL ) {     function(to_email, subject, message) {         email <- emayili::envelope() |>             emayili::from(from_email) |>             emayili::to(to_email) |>             emayili::subject(subject) |>             emayili::text(message)         smtp <- emayili::server(             email_host,             email_port,             email_username,             email_password         )         smtp(email, verbose = FALSE)     } }

code: library(shiny) library(login)  ###### User Interface ########################################################## ui <- fluidPage(     titlePanel("Shiny Login Simple Demo"),     p("You can login with 'test/test'."),     login::login_ui(id = 'login_demo'),     login::logout_button('login_demo'),     hr(),     div('Are you logged in? ', textOutput('is_logged_in')),     div('Username: ', textOutput('username')),     login::is_logged_in(         id = 'login_demo',         div("This only shows when you are logged in!")     ),     login::is_not_logged_in(         id = 'login_demo',         div("This only shows when you are NOT logged in!")     ) )  ##### Server ################################################################### server <- function(input, output, session) {     USER <- login::login_server(         id = 'login_demo',         db_conn = RSQLite::dbConnect(RSQLite::SQLite(), 'users.sqlite')     )      observeEvent(USER$logged_in, {         if(USER$logged_in) {             shinyjs::hide(id = 'login_box')         } else {             shinyjs::show(id = "login_box")         }     })      output$is_logged_in <- renderText({         USER$logged_in     })      output$username <- renderText({         USER$username     }) }  ##### Run the application ###################################################### if(interactive()) {     shinyApp(ui = ui, server = server) }
